items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely this afternoon, overnight tonight and into tomorrow morning. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry road in Horning. Be ready to take action to protect your property if flooding is expected. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Thursday 2nd December 2021.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
River and lake levels are high but steady on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water due to heavy rainfall.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around The Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water.
The forecast is mostly dry for today and tomorrow and river and lake levels are forecast to fall.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 02/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Duddon, River Crake, Mill Beck

items.message: River levels remain high on the Rivers Esk and Irthing due to last nights heavy rainfall. River levels are forecast to fall throughout the day. Areas most at risk include Rivers Esk and Irthing and other watercourses, including low lying areas around Longtown and Brampton. The forecast is mostly dry from today, 01/12/2021. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 02/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high on the Lower River Eden due to last nights heavy rainfall. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Lower River Eden, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around River Eden and its tributaries from its confluence with the River Irthing through Crosby-on-Eden and Carlisle to the Solway Firth at Rockcliffe. The forecast is mostly dry from today, 01/12/2021 and river levels are forecast to begin falling. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 02/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

This flood alert has been removed as river levels peaked overnight and are now falling.  No further flooding is currently expected in this area. Please see the gov.uk website for a 5 day flood forecast and river levels.

River levels have risen as a result of snow-melt and additional rainfall overnight on 30/11/21. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is possible from 13:00 01/12/21. Areas most at risk are low lying land around the River Rye and it's tributaries, including Ralsdale Beck, River Seph, Ledge Beck, Fangdale Beck, Prodale Beck, Ladhill Beck, Etton Gill, Borough Beck and Spittle Beck. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  This message will be updated this evening 01/12/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Shardlow river gauge. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane, and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high  into this evening, 01/12/2021.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated this afternoon, 01/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels will continue to remain high during Wednesday 01/12/21. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is possible. The area most at risk is Briggswath. We expect river levels to fall slightly this morning and to rise slightly this afternoon, Wednesday 01/12/21. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast.  Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.   This message will be updated in 8 hours or as the situation changes.

River levels will continue to remain high during Wednesday 01/12/21.  Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland will continue throughout Wednesday 01/12/2021.  Areas most at risk are low lying land around the River Seven and it's tributaries, including Northdale Beck, Hartoft Beck, Ings Beck, Lastingham Beck, Sutherland Beck, Cropton Beck and Catter Beck.  We expect river levels to fall slightly this morning and to rise slightly this afternoon, Wednesday 01/12/21. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. This message will be updated  in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

River levels will continue to remain high during Wednesday 01/12/21. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland will continue into late into Wednesday evening, 01/12/21. Areas most at risk are low lying land around the River Riccal and it's tributaries, including Bonfield Gill, Bogmire Gill, Ellerker Beck, Keld Spring Beck and Walmouth Beck. We expect river levels to fall slightly later this morning, and to rise again this afternoon, Wednesday 01/12/21.Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. This message will be updated  in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Swale, Cod Beck, Bedale Beck

items.message: River levels will continue to remain high during Wednesday 01/12/21.    Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is possible.  Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads. We expect river levels to start to fall late Wednesday 01/12/21. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast.  Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated in 8 hours or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast from Whitby to Filey

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire

items.message: Strong winds are expected to cause large waves and spray overtopping along the North Yorkshire Coast on Wednesday 1st December, between 17:30-18:45 and tomorrow morning, Thursday 2nd December between 04:30-06:15. Hazardous conditions might extend 2 hours either side of the high tide. The particular areas at risk are exposed areas of the coast around Scarborough, particularly low lying paths around Scarborough South Bay. Please be careful along beaches, coastal footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous with debris. We will continue to monitor the forecast and levels closely. This message will be updated this evening, Wednesday 1st December 2021, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ure, Swinney Beck, Bishop Monkton Beck, River Skell, River Laver, River Tutt, Stainley Beck

items.message: River levels will continue to remain high during Wednesday 01/12/21. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is possible.  Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads. We expect river levels to peak at Boroughbridge early evening on Wednesday 01/12/21. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast.  Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated in 8 hours or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ouse, Burdyke, Holgate Beck, Blue Beck, River Foss, The Fleet

items.message: River levels have risen as a result of snow-melt, and additional rainfall overnight on 30/11/2021.  Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is possible today, 01/12/21.  Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads. We expect river levels to remain high into the early hours on Thursday 02/12/21. We plan to operate the Foss Barrier on Wednesday 01/12/21. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast.  Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  This message will be updated in 8 hours or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby
items.message: River levels have risen as a result of snow-melt, and additional rainfall overnight on 30/11/2021.  Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is possible today, 01/12/21.  Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads. We expect river levels to remain high into the early hours of Thursday 02/12/21, around the Naburn area. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast.  Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  This message will be updated in 8 hours or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely, between 20:45pm and 22:45pm tonight, Wednesday 1st December 2021. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front, may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon, may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it, is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.74mAODN at 21:45pm tonight, Wednesday 1st December 2021, which is 0.60m above tide tables, wind Force 6, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 10:00am tomorrow, Thursday 2nd December 2021.

items.description: The Suffolk and Essex coast from Felixstowe to Clacton including Orwell and Stour estuaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, River Orwell, River Deben

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 20:15pm and 22:15pm tonight, Wednesday 1st December 2021. The flood gates at Felixstowe seafront will be closed. The waterfront at Pin Mill, and The Strand at Wherstead under the Orwell Bridge may be flooded. Water may be on the quay at Mistley. The detailed forecast for those that use it, is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.59mAODN at 21:15pm tonight, Wednesday 1st December 2021, which is 0.77m above tide tables, wind Force 6, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 10:00am tomorrow, Thursday 2nd December 2021.

This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely, between 20:15pm and 22:15pm tonight, Wednesday 1st December 2021. Tide levels will be high around the boat yard in Felixstowe Ferry hamlet at the end of Ferry Road, and along riverside areas in Woodbridge and Waldringfield, as well as in surrounding marshland. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.59mAODN at 21:15pm tonight, Wednesday 1st December 2021, which is 0.77m above tide tables, wind Force 6, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate.  We will update this message by 10:00am tomorrow, Thursday 2nd December 2021.

items.description: North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby including tidal River Esk
items.message: This flood alert has been issued in response to wave action and spray on Wednesday (01/12/21), expected between 14:00 and 17:45. The particular area of concern is Sandsend. Please take care around exposed coastal roads and footpaths. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. This message will be updated by 18:00 on Wednesday 01/12/21.

floodArea.county: County Durham, Hartlepool, North Tyneside, South Tyneside, Sunderland

items.message:
Large and powerful waves are expected to overtop sea defences at Seaham Harbour and docks as a result of high tides and strong winds. High tides are expected at 13:00 today, 01/12/2021 however strong waves are anticipated throughout day with wave overtopping possible between 12:15 and 15:15 today, 01/12/2021. Areas most at risk are beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.  

This message will be updated by 17:00 today, 01/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Suffolk coast from Lowestoft to Bawdsey
items.message: This message has been issued, because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 6:00pm to 8:00pm today, 1st December 2021.  We expect to see high water levels in Lake Lothing in Lowestoft. As well as high sea levels along the Suffolk Coast, impacting on beach access points. The detailed forecast for those that use it, is for a peak level at Lowestoft of 1.81mAODN at 7:00pm, on Wednesday 1st December 2021, which is 0.76m above tide tables, wind Force 7, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). The 7:00am tide on 2nd December 2021, is also currently forecast to be a Flood Alert. We will update the information on the internet before that tide. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation. We will update the internet message with detailed information, for tomorrows tide by 9pm Wednesday 1st December 2021.

This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely, between 6:00pm to 8:00pm today, 1st December 2021. We expect high tide levels at the harbourside in Southwold. The detailed forecast for those that use it, is for a peak level at Lowestoft of 1.81mAODN at 7:00pm, on Wednesday 1st December 2021, which is 0.76m above tide tables, wind Force 7, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). The 7:00am tide, on 2nd December 2021 is also currently forecast to be a Flood Alert. We will update the information on the internet before that tide. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation. We will update the internet message with detailed information for tomorrows tide, by 9pm Wednesday 1st December 2021.

items.description: The tidal River Waveney from Ellingham to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely this afternoon, overnight tonight and into tomorrow morning. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels at Beccles Quay.   Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself or others at risk. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Thursday 2nd December 2021.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely this afternoon, overnight tonight and into tomorrow morning. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas. Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself or others at risk. We are monitoring the situation and will issue further warnings as required. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Thursday 2nd December 2021.

items.description: Riverside properties along the tidal River Yare including Cantley, Brundall and Reedham
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely this afternoon, overnight tonight and into tomorrow morning. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. Areas most at risk are in Reedham, Cantley and Brundall. Roads affected include Ferry Road in Reedham, the A47 and the railway line between Reedham and Brundall. Be ready to take action to protect your property if flooding is expected. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Thursday 2nd December 2021.

Overtopping waves and spray are expected as a result of strong onshore winds.  Consequently, flooding of coastal areas is expected between 15:00 and 17:00 today 01/12/21. Areas most at risk are properties at Sandsend. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast.  Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads, as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.  This message will be updated by 18:00  this afternoon, 01/12/21, or as the situation changes

This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We continue to monitor the situation.

River levels are high on the Upper Coquet as a result of heavy rainfall and snowmelt overnight. Areas most at risk are riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads. Further rainfall is forecast through today, Wednesday 01/12/2021. We expect river levels to remain high throughout the day. 

We are closely monitoring the situation and do not currently expect to issue any Flood Warnings. Our incident response staff will be opening Rothbury gates in the next hour (12:00-13:00pm, 01/12/2021). Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.

This message will be updated by 18:00 this evening, 01/12/2021.

floodArea.county: County Durham, Darlington, Hartlepool, Middlesbrough, North Yorkshire, Stockton-on-Tees

items.message:
River levels are rising on the Lower Tees as a result of heavy rainfall and snowmelt. Areas most at risk are riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads. Further rainfall is forecast through today, Wednesday 01/12/2021. We expect river levels to remain high throughout the day.

We are closely monitoring the situation and do not currently expect to issue any Flood Warnings. Our incident response staff have closed the Yarm flood gates and they will remain closed through today, 01/12/2021. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  

This message will be updated by 18:00 this evening, 01/12/2021.

We are closely monitoring the situation and do not currently expect to issue any Flood Warnings. Our incident response staff have closed the Croft and Neasham flood gates, and they will remain closed through the day. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.
